qas.question: What is subject to a space-time complexity trade off?
What type of scheme involves trade offs among other things?
What is subject to a space-time hardware?
What type of scheme involves storage among other things?
What must compressed data be to be inconvenient?
What does extra processing impose through distortion?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Compression<b4_0/><a0_0/> is useful because it helps reduce resource usage, such as data storage space or transmission capacity. Because <a1_0>compressed data<a1_0/> must be <b7_0>decompressed<b7_0/> to use, this extra processing imposes <b8_0>computational or other costs<b8_0/> through decompression; this situation is far from being a free lunch. <a2_0><b5_0>Data compression<b5_0/><a2_0/> is subject to a space–time complexity trade-off. For instance, a compression scheme for video may require expensive hardware for the video to be decompressed fast enough to be viewed as it is being decompressed, and the option to decompress the video in full before watching it may be inconvenient or require additional storage. The design of <a3_0><b6_0>data compression<b6_0/><a3_0/> schemes involves trade-offs among various factors, including the degree of compression, the amount of distortion introduced (when using lossy data compression), and the computational resources required to compress and decompress the data.
